definitions: To drain something completely of its resources, especially money or people, over a period of time.
To allow a wound to bleed freely to remove contaminants or reduce pressure.
To extract information or resources slowly and completely.
examples: The company's poor management decisions began to bleed its assets out.
The doctor decided to bleed the wound out to prevent infection.
They tried to bleed the truth out of the reluctant witness.
pastTenses: bled sth out, bled sth out
